Finding the antiderivative for a constant function (rectangle) also leads to finding the area of the rectangle by just the considering two points (corners). Where the points of the antiderivative end up in the X-Y coordinate system is how calculus works. We never realize width times height is calculus. We forget we are depending on the rectangle sides being infinitely straight between the four corners without confirming each infinite point along the shape.

As for “that’s just crazy to me”: I do not know if it was covered already in another of your excellent videos, or mentioned already in the many comments, but ISTM that this seemingly “crazy” fact that we can seemingly ignore all the information between the upper and lower bound has a very simple explanation that maybe should be covered in another video:

If one thinks about this carefully, we end up adding something like (I do not know if it is entirely proper mathematical notation)

I = ∫ₐᵇ f(x) dx
= ∫ₐᵇ dF(x)/dx dx
= lim_{dx→0} {[F(a + dx) − F(a)] dx + [F(a + 2 dx) − F(a + dx)] dx + … + [F(b − dx) − F(b − 2 dx)] dx + [F(b) − F(b − dx)] dx}.

We can extract the common factor dx:

I = lim_{dx→0} {[F(a + dx) − F(a) + F(a + 2 dx) − F(a + dx) + … + F(b − 2 dx) − … + F(b − dx) − F(b − 2 dx) + F(b) − F(b − dx)] dx}

Due to commutativity of addition, we can rearrange this:

I = lim_{dx→0} {[−F(a) + F(a + dx) − F(a + dx) + F(a + 2 dx) − F(a + 2 dx) + … + F(b − 2 dx) − F(b − 2 dx) + F(b − dx) − F(b − dx) + F(b)] dx}
= lim_{dx→0} {[−F(a) + 0 + 0 + … + 0 + 0 + F(b)] dx}
= lim_{dx→0} {[F(b) − F(a)] dx}
= F(b) − F(a).

That is, because we are considering the information in-between, we can “ignore” it as the intermediate terms all cancel.

I tried to see myself that if the fundamental theorem is TRUE in general,but in a weird way
Let f(x) be the function whose integration we want to do from x=a and x=b. The sum of the areas of rectangular strips will be f(a)da +f(a+da)da+........+f(a+(N-1)da)da
where da is the width of strip and N is no of strips. Notice that N=b-a/da
Now let F(x) be the function whose derivative is f(x). So at x=a, the limit of [F(a+da)-F(a)]/da when da tends to be 0 is f(a) and similarly for other points like (a+da)..... . So in the process of summing up the areas above I did, I replaced f(a)da by F(a+da)-F(a) ; and similarly replaced other terms and got
F(a+da) - F(a) +F(a+2da)-F(a)+....+ F(a+Nda)-F(a), which simplifies to
-NF(a)+F(a+da) + F(a+2da)+..... + F(a+Nda). But Nda equals b-a so putting b-a in place of Nda and putting remaining (da) s equal to 0 we get -NF(a) +F(a) +F(a) +..... +F(b) which further simplifies -NF(a) +(N-1)F(a)+F(b) which is equal to F(b) - F(a) and it gives the fundamental theorem of calculus. Hope it is all correct.

I think I have a super simple proof of the fundamental theorem: We have an unkown area function A(x) (which we want to find out) that finds the area between f(x) and the x-axis between x=a and x. If h>0 is a small number we can approximate the area A(x+h)-A(x) as the area of a rectangle with the width h and height f(x). In other words: A(x+h)-A(x)≈h*f(x). REWRITE: [A(x+h)-A(x)]/h≈f(x)
Now, take the limit as h goes to 0 on both side --> A'(x)=f(x)
(f(x) is assumed to be contiunous around the point x).
-->A(x)=F(x)+C. To find C plug in A(a)=0 --> C=F(a). Then if we want to find the area between x=a and x=b A(b)=F(b)-F(a) :)

I just realized that ds is the anti-derivative. Since ds = v(t)*dt, anti-derivatives represent area, and therefore, each anti-derivative is an integral, and therefore when we subtract the area function at the upper bound by the one at the lower bound we are erasing redundancy in order to get the value of area and the value of our integral.

The conceptual jump is realizing that ds = v(t)*dt and therefore ds/dt = v(t). And the other way, since ds/dt = v(t), ds = v(t)*dt.

The whole point of this is that since all we're given in an integral problem is the function f(x) inside the integral notation, we're forced to realize that something whose derivative = f(x) represents area because it's dy = f(x)*dx. And thus, dy/dx = f(x) <-- our only given piece of information.

You have to know a priori what will give the f(x) through familiarity of the derivative, or you'll have to know the formal limit definition of the integral using partitions, and solve the limit.

There's one thing you could have done to clarify the relationship between f and F and why the integral simplifies to removing one value of another: add the graph of F to the graph of f, and explain how at each interval from 0 to T you have added all the little dx together and that at T, in F(T) you have the total sum of all the values of f(t) from 0 to T. You could make a nice animation of grabbing the dx rectangle of the next f(T+dx) and moving it from the top of F(T) to form F(T+dx). This is why the integral formula is so simple (after going through the pain of finding it) and this is also why calculating integral values is as simple as keeping a running sum of the total at each instance (the car and spedometer example, you don't even have to be sure of the formula for f(t) as long as you have the values for it, you can still just add the values at each timestep to get the integral [which leads into how a PID controller works ;) ]).

On a more serious note, these videos are very well done. It's great to see the fundamentals (huehuehue) of mathematics being explained in such an intuitive manner. I think I could use your videos to help my own content, which is mostly geared towards higher-level undergrad/graduate science/math. If I incorporate animations and an intuitive angle, I imagine the explanations I give could get even better. Thank you for making these lessons!
